    \[h = (2 \space \frac{\sqrt{6}}{3} + 1) \space a\]

    a = edge length

    Area

    \[A = \frac{3}{2} \space (2 + \sqrt{3}) \space a^2\]

    Volume

    \[V = \frac{(2 \sqrt{2} + 3 \sqrt{3})}{12} \space a^3\]

    Pentagonal Bipyramid (Decahedron)

    a = side of Regular Pentagonal Bipyramid

    Total Surface area

    \[S= (\frac{5\sqrt{3}}{2})a^2 \]

    Height

    \[h= 2 \space (\sqrt{\frac{(5 - \sqrt{5})}{10}}) \times a \]

    Volume

    \[V=( \frac{5+\sqrt{5}}{12})a^3 \]

    Hexagonal Pyramid
    Base Area

    \[A = 3ab \]

    a = apothem

    b = base length


    Volume

    \[V = abh \]

    h = height

    Total Surface area

    \[S = 3b(a + s) \]

    s = slant height

    Lateral Surface area

    \[LSA = \frac{1}{2}(Perimeter \times s) \]

    Octagonal Pyramid
    Base Area

    \[BA = 2s^2 \space cot(22.5 \degree)\]

    s = side


    Volume

    \[V = \frac{2}{3} \space hs^2 \space cot(22.5 \degree) \]

    Total Surface area

    \[TSA = 2s \space (\sqrt{4h^2 + s^2 \space cot^2(22.5 \degree)} \space + \space \]

    \[s \space cot(22.5 \degree)\space)\]

    Lateral Surface area

    \[LSA = 2s \sqrt{4h^2 + s^2 \space cot^2(22.5 \degree)} \]


    Wedge
    Volume

    \[V = \frac{bh}{6} (2a+c) \]

    Lateral Surface area

    \[F = \frac{a+c}{2} \space \sqrt{4h^2 + b^2} + b\sqrt{h^2 + (a-c)^2} \]

    Surface area

    \[S = F \space + \space ab \]


    Wedge Cuboid
    Volume(V)

    \[abh_{1} + ab(h_{2} - h_{1})/2\]

    Surface area(A)

    \[ab + sb + bh_{1} + bh_{2} + a(h_{1} + h_{2}) \]

    Short diagonal(d1)

    \[\sqrt{a^2 + b^2 + h_{1} ^2}\]

    Long diagonal(d2)

    \[ \sqrt{a^2 + b^2 + h_{2} ^2}\]



    Slant height(s)

    \[\sqrt{a^2 + (h_{2} - h_{1})^2}\]

    Surface area

    \[A = ab+2ac+hb \]

    Height

    \[h = \sqrt{\frac{4*c^2-b^2}{4}} \]

    Hyperboloid

    In geometry, a hyperboloid of revolution, sometimes called a circular hyperboloid, is the surface generated by rotating a hyperbola around one of its principal axes. A hyperboloid is the surface obtained from a hyperboloid of revolution by deforming it by means of directional scalings, or more generally, of an affine transformation.

    Equation

    \[\frac{x^{2}}{a^{2}} +\frac{y^{2}}{b^{2}}-\frac{z^{2}}{c^{2}}=1\]

    Volume

    \[\frac{2\pi h a^{2}}{b^{2}}(b^{2}+\frac{h^{2}}{3})\]







    Parallelepiped
    Volume

    \[V=abc\]


    Diagonal

    \[\sqrt{a^{2}+b^{2}+c^{2}}\]


    Surface Area

    \[S=2ab+2bc+2ca)\]







    Rhombohedron
    Second angle (Î²)

    \[Î² = 180 \degree - Î±\]


    Volume (V)

    \[V=a^3 (1 - \cos{(Î±)}) \sqrt{ 1 + 2 \cos{(Î±)}}\]


    Surface Area (S)

    \[S= 6 \times a^2 \times \sin{(Î±)}\]


    It is a parallelepiped with six equal faces






    Half Tetrahedron
    Volume (V)

    \[V = \frac{a^3 \times \sqrt{2}}{24}\]

    Area (A)

    \[A = a^2 \times \Big(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{1}{4} \Big)\]

    Half Edge (b)

    \[b= \frac{a}{2}\]

    Height (h)

    \[h= \frac{a \times \sqrt{6}}{6}\]





    Spheroidal Cap
    Volume

    \[V= \frac{\pi a^2 h^2}{3 c^2 } (3c - h )\]



    Base Area

    \[B = \pi a^2 (1- (1- \frac{h}{c})^2 )\]






    Spherical Shell
    Volume

    \[V= \frac{4}{3} \pi (R^3-r^3)\]

    Area

    \[A= 4 \pi (R^2+r^2)\]

    Shell Thickness

    \[a= R-r\]



    Cylindrical Shell
    Volume

    \[V= \pi h (R^2-r^2)\]

    Surface Area

    \[A=2 \pi \times (R+r) \times (R-r+h)\]

    Lateral Surface Area

    \[L= 2 \pi \times h \times (R+r)\]

    Oblique Cylindrical Shell
    Volume

    \[V= \pi h (R^2-r^2)\]

    Surface Area

    \[A=2 \pi [(R+r) \times a + (R^2-r^2)]\]

    Height

    \[h = a \times sin(\alpha)\]

    Surface Area

    Torus

    \[A=(2 \times \pi \times R)(2 \times \pi \times r)\]

    Obelisk
    Lateral Surface area (L)

    \[L = (a+b) \times \]

    \[\sqrt{(a-b)^2 + 4i^2 } + b \]

    \[\times \sqrt{4 \times j^2 + b^2} \]


    Surface area (A)

    \[A = a^2 + L \]


    Volume (V)

    \[V = \frac{i \times [ (a^2 + b^2) + \sqrt{a^2 \times b^2}] + b^2 \times j}{3} \]


    N-dimension Sphere

    Volume


    \[V=\frac{\pi ^{\frac{n}{2}}r^{n}}{\Gamma \left ( \frac{n}{2}+1 \right )}\]

    r = Radius

    n = Number of dimensions


    Surface area


    \[S=\frac{2\pi ^{\frac{n}{2}}r^{n-1}}{\Gamma \left ( \frac{n}{2} \right )}\]




    Trapezoid

    Area


    \[H*\frac{(A+B)}{2}\]

    H=Height

    A & B= Two parallel Side


    Volume


    \[H Ã— h Ã— \frac{(b1 + b2)}{2}\]

    H=Height of trapezoid

    H=Height of prism

    b1 & b2= Base of Trapezoid



    Length

    Energy

    International Number Conversion

    Roman/Arabic Numeral

    our

    Armstrong Number Checker


    In numerical number theory, the Armstrong number definition is the number in any given number base, which forms the total of the same number, when each of its digits is raised to the power of the number of digits in the number.





    Disarium Number Checker


    A number is called Disarium if sum of its digits powered with their respective positions is equal to the number itself.




    Neon Number Checker


    A neon number is a number where the sum of digits of square of the number is equal to the number.




    Krishnamurthy Number Checker


    A Krishnamurthy number is a number whose sum of the factorial of digits is equal to the number itself.




    Automorphic number Checker


    A number is called Automorphic number if and only if its square ends in the same digits as the number itself.





    Pronic number Checker


    Pronic number is a number which is the product of two consecutive integers, that is, a number n is a product of x and (x+1).




    Harshad Number Checker


    An integer number in base 10 which is divisible by the sum of its digits is said to be a Harshad Number.
